bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, January 22, 1901

div1.p: Howard indicates that he is not certain of the grounds for believing that there is another species of mosquito to be considered, but he makes a guess, and agrees that the distinction is important to Reed's work. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, January 22, 1901
div1.p:
I have yours of the 15th. Theobald has
not told me the grounds on which he makes a new genus of
taeniatus, but I imagine it must be the tarsal claws of the
male. I am just figuring a larva of this species, secured
last summer at Virginia Beach (the northernmost locality
known to me) and find that it differs from the normal Culex
larva, at all events as these characters occur in C. pungens.
I agree with you that the structural separation of this
species from Culex is most significant in connection with
your discoveries. I hope to see an early copy of your
paper for the Pan-American Congress.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L.O. Howard Dr. Walter Reed, U. S. A.,
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba.
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES OF THE UNITED STATES
LITTERA
SCRIPTA
MANET
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of
Entomology and Plant Quarantine.
Three Centimeters
